parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Active - Accusative Masculine Singular
str2: A primary verb; properly, to lead; by implication, to bring, drive, go, pass, or induce.
Much, many; often.
A son, descendent. Apparently a primary word; a 'son', used very widely of immediate, remote or figuratively, kinship.
A primary preposition; to or into, of place, time, or purpose; also in adverbial phrases.
From the base of dokeo; glory, in a wide application.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: It becomes, is fitting to, is right. Apparently a primary verb; to tower up, i.e. to be suitable or proper.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative Masculine 3rd Person Singular
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.
A primary preposition denoting the channel of an act; through.

parse: Personal / Relative Pronoun - Accusative Masculine Singular
str2: Who, which, what, that.
And, even, also, namely.
A primary preposition denoting the channel of an act; through.

parse: Personal / Relative Pronoun - Genitive Masculine Singular
str2: Who, which, what, that.
All, the whole, every kind of. Including all the forms of declension; apparently a primary word; all, any, every, the whole.
From teleios; to complete, i.e. accomplish, or consummate.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Originator, author, founder, prince, leader. From arche and ago; a chief leader.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive Masculine 3rd Person Plural
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.
Feminine of a derivative of soter as noun; rescue or safety.
A primary preposition denoting the channel of an act; through.
From a presumed derivative of pathos; something undergone, i.e. Hardship or pain; subjectively, an emotion or influence.
